comment.description: The application protocol of the traffic.
The 802.11 channel used by a wireless network.
This field is automatically provided by asset and identity correlation features of applications like Splunk Enterprise Security. Do not define extractions for this field when writing add-ons.
This field is automatically provided by asset and identity correlation features of applications like Splunk Enterprise Security. Do not define extractions for this field when writing add-ons.
The interface that is listening remotely or receiving packets locally. Can also be referred to as the 'egress interface.'
The IP address of the destination.

The destination TCP/IP layer 2 Media Access Control (MAC) address of a packet's destination, such as 06:10:9f:eb:8f:14. Note: Always force lower case on this field and use colons instead of dashes, spaces, or no separator.
The destination priority, if applicable.
The NATed IPv4 or IPv6 address to which a packet has been sent.
The NATed port to which a packet has been sent. Note: Do not translate the values of this field to strings (tcp/80 is 80, not http).
The network zone of the destination.
The direction the packet is traveling.
The amount of time for the completion of the network event, in seconds.
The ip address of the device.
This field is automatically provided by asset and identity correlation features of applications like Splunk Enterprise Security. Do not define extractions for this field when writing add-ons.
This field is automatically provided by asset and identity correlation features of applications like Splunk Enterprise Security. Do not define extractions for this field when writing add-ons.

The device TCP/IP layer 2 Media Access Control (MAC) address of a packet's destination, such as 06:10:9f:eb:8f:14. Note: Always force lower case on this field and use colons instead of dashes, spaces, or no separator.
This field is automatically provided by asset and identity correlation features of applications like Splunk Enterprise Security. Do not define extractions for this field when writing add-ons.
The network zone of the device.
Unique identifier for this traffic stream, such as a netflow, jflow, or cflow.
The RFC 2780 or RFC 4443 human-readable code value of the traffic, such as Destination Unreachable or Parameter Problem . See the ICMP Type Numbers and the ICMPv6 Type Numbers.
The RFC 2780 or RFC 4443 numeric value of the traffic. See the ICMP Type Numbers and the ICMPv6 Type Numbers.
The numeric identifier of the process assigned by the operating system.
The OSI layer 3 (network) protocol of the traffic observed, in lower case. For example, ip, appletalk, ipx.
Version of the OSI layer 3 protocol.
The amount of time it took to receive a response in the network event, in seconds.
The session identifier. Multiple transactions build a session.
The business unit of the network traffic source.
The category of the network traffic source.
The interface that is listening locally or sending packets remotely. Can also be referred to as the 'ingress interface.'
The ip address of the source.

The source TCP/IP layer 2 Media Access Control (MAC) address of a packet's destination, such as 06:10:9f:eb:8f:14. Note: Always force lower case on this field and use colons instead of dashes, spaces, or no separator.
The priority of the source, if applicable.
The NATed IPv4 or IPv6 address from which a packet has been sent.
The NATed port from which a packet has been sent. Note: Do not translate the values of this field to strings (tcp/80 is 80, not http).
The network zone of the source.
The 802.11 service set identifier (ssid) assigned to a wireless session.
This automatically generated field is used to access tags from within data models. Add-on builders do not need to populate it.
The TCP flag or multiple flags specified in the event.
The combination of source and destination IP ToS (type of service) values in the event.
The 'time to live' of a packet or diagram, in seconds.
This field is automatically provided by asset and identity correlation features of applications like Splunk Enterprise Security. Do not define extractions for this field when writing add-ons.
This field is automatically provided by asset and identity correlation features of applications like Splunk Enterprise Security. Do not define extractions for this field when writing add-ons.
This field is automatically provided by asset and identity correlation features of applications like Splunk Enterprise Security. Do not define extractions for this field when writing add-ons.
The virtual local area network (VLAN) specified in the record.
The wireless standard(s) in use, such as 802.11a, 802.11b, 802.11g, or 802.11n.
The action taken by the network device.
Total count of bytes handled by this device/interface (bytes_in + bytes_out).
How many bytes this device/interface received.
How many bytes this device/interface transmitted.
The destination of the network traffic (the remote host). You can alias this from more specific fields, such as dest_host, dest_ip, or dest_name.
The destination port of the network traffic. Note: Do not translate the value of this field to a string (tcp/80 is 80, not http). You can set up the corresponding string value in the dest_svc field.
The device that reported the traffic event. You can alias this from more specific fields, such as dvc_host, dvc_ip, or dvc_name.
The total count of packets handled by this device/interface (packets_in + packets_out).
The total count of packets received by this device/interface.
The total count of packets transmitted by this device/interface.

The rule which defines the action that was taken in the network event. Note: This is a string value. Use rule_id for rule fields that are integer data types. The rule_id field is optional, so it is not included in the data model.
The source of the network traffic (the client requesting the connection). You can alias this from more specific fields, such as src_host, src_ip, or src_name.
The source port of the network traffic. Note: Do not translate the value of this field to a string (tcp/80 is 80, not http). You can set up the corresponding string value in the src_svc field.
The OSI layer 4 (transport) protocol of the traffic observed, in lower case.
The user that requested the traffic flow.
The vendor and product of the device generating the network event. This field can be automatically populated by vendor and product fields in your data.

calculations.expression: case(isnotnull(vendor_product),vendor_product,isnotnull(vendor) AND vendor!="unknown" AND isnotnull(product) AND product!="unknown",vendor." ".product,isnotnull(vendor) AND vendor!="unknown" AND (isnull(product) OR product="unknown"),vendor." unknown",(isnull(vendor) OR vendor="unknown") AND isnotnull(product) AND product!="unknown","unknown ".product,isnotnull(sourcetype),sourcetype,1=1,"unknown")
